Honda Element logo

The **Honda Element** is a [compact](/wiki/Compact_car "Compact car")
[crossover](/wiki/Crossover_\(automobile\) "Crossover \(automobile\)")
manufactured and marketed by [Honda](/wiki/Honda "Honda") and based on a
modified [CR-V](/wiki/Honda_CR-V "Honda CR-V")
[platform](/wiki/Automobile_platform "Automobile platform")

Manufactured in [East Liberty, Ohio](/wiki/East_Liberty,_Ohio "East Liberty,
Ohio"), the Element was offered with [front-wheel](/wiki/Front-wheel_drive
"Front-wheel drive") or [all-wheel drive](/wiki/All-wheel_drive "All-wheel
drive") in the [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") and
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") from model years 2003[2] through 2011.[3]

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Overview")]

The Element followed a concept vehicle called _Model X_ , developed by a core
group of Honda R&D engineers in 1998, debuted at the 2001 North American
International Auto Show in Detroit. The Model X was designed to be an
activity-oriented vehicle combining features of a [pickup
truck](/wiki/Pickup_truck "Pickup truck") and a [sport utility
vehicle](/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle "Sport utility vehicle").[4]

The Element was unveiled at the 2002 New York International Auto Show in March
2002.[1]

The 4-seat Element is optimized to carry large volume loads, limited by total
passenger and cargo weight not exceeding 675 lbs. The floor is made of easily
cleanable TPO coated textured urethane; the fabric is stain resistant; the
individual rear seats recline, fold up, and are removable. The rear clamshell
tailgate arrangement is large, and the vehicle is tall, allowing tall loads.

The rear side doors open outward from the front but are not referred to as
[suicide doors](/wiki/Suicide_door "Suicide door"): they cannot be opened if
the conventional front doors are not open. To accommodate elimination of the
[B-pillars](/wiki/B-pillar "B-pillar"), which provides unobstructed access for
side loading through the 2006 model year, limited by the front seat design
from 2007 onward, the Element features a chassis with reinforced joints,
strengthened lower side sills, larger cross members, enlarged rocker panels,
and five bulkheads per side.

The compact SUV features a [2.4 Litre K Engine](/wiki/Honda_K_engine#K24
"Honda K engine"), an i-VTEC [four-cylinder](/wiki/Straight-4 "Straight-4")
engine producing 166 hp (124 kW) at 5500 rpm and 160 lb·ft (217 N·m) of torque
at 4500 rpm and [front-wheel drive](/wiki/Front-wheel_drive "Front-wheel
drive") or an optional [all-wheel drive](/wiki/All-wheel_drive "All-wheel
drive") system — a hydraulically actuated system that operates only when front
wheel slippage occurs, marketed as "Real Time" all wheel drive. The Element
has a towing capacity of 680 kg, or 1500 lbs.

With projected first year sales of 50,000,[2] the Element sold 67,478 units in
2003 in the U.S.[5] By 2010, just over 14,000 were sold,[3] and by December
2010, shortly before its discontinuation, it had sold a total of more than
325,000 units.[3]

In 2007, the Element won the Dogcars.com "Dog Car of the Year" award because
of its "versatile cargo space, easy-clean flooring, crate-friendly rear design
and optional all-wheel drive."[6] and in 2010 it won the "Small SUV" category
as a "Top Safety Pick" in the [Insurance Institute for Highway
Safety](/wiki/Insurance_Institute_for_Highway_Safety "Insurance Institute for
Highway Safety") Annual Awards.[7]

## Model year
changes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Model year changes")]

### 2003[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: 2003")]

The 2003 Element was launched with two trim levels — DX and EX. All-wheel
drive models came with a large rear skylight.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] with
160 hp. Production and sales began in December 2002.'

### 2004[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: 2004")]

A mid-range LX trim level between the DX and the premium EX trim levels. Side
airbags became available as an option on the EX models.

### 2005[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: 2005")]

The LX model was introduced with more standard
features.[_[vague](/wiki/Wikipedia:Vagueness "Wikipedia:Vagueness")_]
Improvements were made to the front seats as well as the inclusion of an
armrest for the passenger's side captain's chair. The DX model was eliminated.
[XM satellite radio](/wiki/XM_satellite_radio "XM satellite radio") and
[MP3](/wiki/MP3 "MP3") capabilities were added as standard features in the
audio system for the EX model. The charcoal gray plastic tone was darkened and
a navy blue was offered with the Satin Silver Metallic paint. Wheel covers on
the LX were changed to mimic the styled alloy wheels. Fuel economy was
officially 19 miles per US gallon (12.4 l/100 km) City, 23 miles per US gallon
(10.2 l/100 km) Highway; 20 miles per US gallon (11.8 l/100 km) Combined[8]

### 2006[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: 2006")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/2006_Honda_Element_EX-P.jpg/200px-2006_Honda_Element_EX-P.jpg)](/wiki/File:2006_Honda_Element_EX-P.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2006_Honda_Element_EX-P.jpg "Enlarge")

2006 Honda Element EX-P

A fully painted version called the EX-P became available for an extra US$500.
It came with a 5-speed [manual transmission](/wiki/Manual_transmission "Manual
transmission") or an optional 4-speed [automatic
transmission](/wiki/Automatic_transmission "Automatic transmission") with
[overdrive](/wiki/Overdrive_\(mechanics\) "Overdrive \(mechanics\)").

### 2007[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: 2007")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Honda_Element_EX_--
_10-30-2009.jpg/200px-Honda_Element_EX_--
_10-30-2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:Honda_Element_EX_--_10-30-2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Honda_Element_EX_--_10-30-2009.jpg "Enlarge")

2007–2008 Honda Element EX

The 2007 Element received a mild refresh, which included 10
[hp](/wiki/Horsepower "Horsepower") increase to 166 hp, along with a 5-speed
automatic transmission, and seat belts integral to the front seats allowing
rear-seat occupants to exit the vehicle without a front occupant having to
unbuckle. Side airbags became standard, as did [electronic stability
control](/wiki/Electronic_stability_control "Electronic stability control").
The plastic latticework grille was replaced by silver-colored slats.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/07-08_Honda_Element_SC.jpg/200px-07-08_Honda_Element_SC.jpg)](/wiki/File:07-08_Honda_Element_SC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:07-08_Honda_Element_SC.jpg "Enlarge")

2007–2008 Honda Element SC

A new trim level called the SC was offered with a different front bumper and
grille, lowered suspension and 18-inch alloy wheels, projector
[headlamps](/wiki/Headlamp "Headlamp"), "tribal print" seat fabric, center
console, and carpeted floors in the seating areas. Unlike the other trim
packages, the SC had a non-removable center console.

### 2008[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: 2008")]

The only change from the 2007 Element was the addition of the color Royal Blue
Pearl for the SC trim.[9]

### 2009[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: 2009")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/2009-2010_Honda_Element_
--_01-13-2010.jpg/220px-2009-2010_Honda_Element_--
_01-13-2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:2009-2010_Honda_Element_--_01-13-2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2009-2010_Honda_Element_--_01-13-2010.jpg "Enlarge")

2009–2011 Honda Element

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/2009_Honda_Element_SC
--DC.jpg/220px-2009_Honda_Element_SC--
DC.jpg)](/wiki/File:2009_Honda_Element_SC--DC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2009_Honda_Element_SC--DC.jpg "Enlarge")

2009 Honda Element SC

New color combinations for the dashboard became available.[10]

For 2009, the Honda Element got a navigation option and some cosmetic changes
to the exterior. The hood and grill were redesigned, the front fenders were
now all metal rather than painted composite material,[10] and the wheel arches
were squared off.[10] The moon-roof was no longer available for 2009-2011.

### 2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: 2010")]

For 2010, Honda Element came with LX, EX, EX with Navigation, and SC models.
However, for all models the Element only came with 5-speed automatic
transmissions and no longer carried the manual transmission versions[11].

### 2011[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: 2011")]

For 2011, the Element no longer carried the SC model and the Royal Blue Pearl
color was also cancelled. Honda discontinued the Element in early 2011.

## Advertising and
marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Advertising and marketing")]

### Gil the
Crab[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Gil the Crab")]

After a summer break, Honda decided to bring back a portion of the "Element
and Friends" ad campaign, but with a focus on the [crab](/wiki/Crab "Crab"),
who was given the name Gil.[12] The most popular character from the ads with
his "I Pinch!" catch phrase, Gil had a [myspace](/wiki/Myspace "Myspace")
page[13] to chronicle Gil's trouble with the law. In order to tap into [social
networking sites](/wiki/Social_network_service "Social network service"),
which began to play larger roles in ad campaigns in the mid-2000s, Gil was to
maintain a [blog](/wiki/Blog "Blog") and promote an [online
petition](/wiki/Internet_petition "Internet petition") to save his job.[14]
and endorse Gil paraphernalia through a [website](/wiki/Website "Website").
This led up to the launch of the new
[commercial](/wiki/Television_advertisement "Television advertisement") dubbed
Element TV, which premiered 28 September 2006, and rolled out with the new
Honda Element SC which went on sale that same day.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Element and Friends - version
2.0[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Element and Friends - version 2.0")]

In the fall of 2006, the Element and Friends
(<http://www.elementandfriends.com> website, now defunct) was re-launched with
the introduction of the new Element SC trim. The previous version had the
driving game using the Element EX-P (now simply called the EX) in a desert,
snow topped mountains, forests, and a beach. They now renamed that area "above
ground". A new second option from the main page allows you to select the
Element SC to go "underground" in an urbanesque environment featuring a drive-
in, central park with a basketball court, a seedy mainstreet, and project
housing. The six new SC friends include a rat, mole, hamster, pigeon, roach,
and a dog. The drive-in serves as the venue to view the TV spots that feature
only the rat, mole, pigeon, and hamster. The format remains the same with new
mini-games, but both maps now include a tunnel to venture above or below the
surface, through the mountain and building respectively. Changes to the above
ground include the removal of the previous TV spots from the website and a
link on the beach to Gil's Myspace page.

RPA,[15] the company which created the Element and friends website, won the
"Best in Show"[16] from MIXX Awards for the [microsite](/wiki/Microsite
"Microsite"). They revealed that visitors average 15 minutes on the site.

### Dog-friendly
Concept[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Dog-friendly Concept")]

    _See "external links" below for dog-friendly concept car photo gallery._

In 2007, the Honda Element won the Dogcars.com's "Dog Car of the Year" award.
Honda chose to follow up on that with a concept vehicle unveiled in 2009 New
York Auto Show specifically designed for canine transportation.[10] It
included a pet restraint system, an extendable cargo area load-in ramp, a 12V
DC rear ventilation fan, second-row seat covers with a simple beige dog-
outline pattern design to match the bed cover fabric, all-season rubber floor
mats with a toy bone pattern, a fan, and "Dog Friendly" exterior pawprint
emblems. A spill-resistant water bowl, also included, could be placed into a
nook in the corner of the pet bed.[10]

The second row pet restraint system was a small net crate suitable for cats or
small dogs, which could be belted into place. It strapped directly to the
lower portion of the seat and the captive animal could not see out the
windows, unlike the pet "booster seats" sold by pet-supply vendors
specifically designed to allow small dogs to see through the windows and sniff
the incoming airflow. The pet bed is a thick cushion for the whole of the rear
cargo area. The cargo area pet restraint system consists of netting on the
sides and the top of the dog bed, as well as a zip-up fourth side to be
secured after the dog is loaded.

The package was dealer-installed and retails for $1,000.[17]

##
Discontinuation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Honda_Element&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Discontinuation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Honda_Element_%289474647182%29.jpg/220px-
Honda_Element_%289474647182%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Honda_Element_\(9474647182\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Honda_Element_\(9474647182\).jpg "Enlarge")

Rear view

Sales of the Element continued to slump throughout the final years of its
production, bottoming out with only 14,000 units in 2009. In 2003 (the
Element's introductory and most successful year), Honda sold more of the cars
than it did in the vehicle's final 3 years combined. Industry analysts and
Honda executives blamed the Element's demise on a variety of factors:
competition from similar vehicles offered by other manufacturers, rivalry
within the automaker's own product line, and a dwindling market share for SUVs
overall.

When Honda unveiled the Element in 2003 the design was unique, and the no-
nonsense philosophy and retro/progressive styling drew customers to the car.
The still emerging and relatively new market for compact SUVs offered little
competition, and Honda was able to win over buyers by targeting the car toward
young, active people with a list of options to suit outdoor activities like
biking and camping. Competing automakers quickly noticed the vehicle's
success, and the Element was quickly joined by similar vehicles such as the
[Nissan Cube](/wiki/Nissan_Cube "Nissan Cube"), [Ford Flex](/wiki/Ford_Flex
"Ford Flex"), [Kia Soul](/wiki/Kia_Soul "Kia Soul") and [Scion
xB](/wiki/Scion_xB "Scion xB"). These other vehicles were similar to the
Element and many of them were more affordable, which proved to be too alluring
for the young audience at which the car had been aimed. In addition to facing
stiff competition from off the lot, the Element also had to cope with intense
rivalry from within the Honda stable in the form of the automaker's flagship
[CR-V](/wiki/Honda_CR-V "Honda CR-V"). The Element model line struggled in the
shadow of this more well-established sister car. Adding to this was Honda
executives' decision not to update the Element at all during the car's entire
9-year production run, a decision that made the Element seem dull and dated in
a market sector that places an extremely high value on ultramodern
contemporary styling and state-of-the-art technology. The model's worst sales
year, 2009, saw the CR-V outselling the Element by a factor of 5 to 1.[18]
[19]

The final model year for the car was 2011 and production ended that April.
